awd_titl_txt: Structures and Electric Fields in Laser-Induced Magnetized Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
Ionized gases, or plasmas, are ubiquitous in nature, for example in lightning, the ionosphere, the sun, and many astrophysical environments. Plasmas are also common in technologies such as gas discharge lamps, microfabrication processes, fusion plasmas, combustion engines, and Hall thrusters. This project will develop new methods based on atomic spectroscopy to monitor the electric and magnetic fields inside of laser-generated laboratory plasmas. This is important because plasma fields are notoriously difficult to monitor, especially for small volumes of plasma, without influencing the particle distributions and fields. The research will pioneer novel quantum technologies that provide non-invasive plasma diagnostics. Shock fronts and ordered structures in plasmas will be studied, as well as the effects of magnetic fields on plasma dynamics. Due to the importance of plasmas in technology, plasma-physics research such as this drives advances in economic competitiveness and prosperity, national defense, space exploration, and communications. It also promotes progress in basic plasma science and astrophysics. Students affiliated with this project will get training that will help them prepare for careers in science, industry and education. 

This study is on small-scale, magnetized, and potentially strongly-coupled, plasmas obtained by laser-induced photo-ionization of atomic vapors.  Both trapped atoms and room-temperature alkali-atom vapor cells will be used. As the photo-generated plasmas expand, they form shock fronts, and in the case of sufficiently strong coupling between ions and electrons the plasmas are expected to develop correlations with crystal-like order.  This project will pioneer novel ways to make position- and time-resolved measurements of the expansion, the shock fronts, and the ordered structures in plasmas. A diagnostic method will be developed using laser spectroscopy with Rydberg atoms and electromagnetically-induced transparency (EIT).  Electric fields in the plasma will be mapped via Rydberg-EIT spectroscopy.  Another diagnostic will use micro-channel plates to count particles that are extracted from the plasma after a variable delay.  The use of field-sensitive Rydberg-state tracer atoms embedded in the plasma as an all-optical diagnostic of macroscopic and random (Holtsmark) electric fields in plasmas may impact other fields in which magnetized plasmas occur, for instance in astrophysics, inertial-confinement and magnetic-confinement fusion, z-pinch studies, and ion trapping. Graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will be trained in atomic and plasma physics research, research presentation, and peer instruction. Students will also gain experience in the construction and operation of scientific apparatus.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The project was focused on the study of small-scale, strongly coupled plasmas. The plasmas were obtained by laser-induced photo-ionization of atomic vapors. Two types of experimental platforms were used, namely cold-atom setups and room-temperature alkali-atom vapor cells. In the cold-atom setups, photo-ionization was employed to prepare small ion plasmas of a few hundred ions. The formation and persistence of shock shells and the presence of strong coupling in the Coulomb-exploding micro-plasmas were measured with a position- and time-resolving micro-channel plate ion detector. The experiment was simulated with molecular-dynamics-style models and with fluid models, verifying shock shells and strong coupling. The computational analysis further enabled the calculation of time- and position-dependent density, temperature, and Coulomb coupling parameter, reaffirming the presence of shock shells and strong coupling in the experiment. The analysis further revealed the time scale of disorder-induced heating, the build-up of pair correlations, adiabatic expansion, and ballistic cooling.

In the vapor-cell component of the project, commercial and custom-fabricated cells were employed to study surface- and plasma-charge effects induced by photo-ionization, photo-electric effects and Penning ionization of photo-exited rubidium vapor in the cells. As an experimental vehicle to study surface and plasma electric fields, electromagnetically-induced transparency of Rydberg atoms was employed for sensitive electric-field measurement in a contact-free, all-optical manner. In this method, the atomic Stark effect of Rydberg atoms allowed sensitive electric-field measurement. Various surface- and volume-charge-generating mechanisms in the vapor cells were observed and modeled.

The experimental and modeling work was accompanied by a theoretical study of cross sections, Cooper minima and shape resonances in the photon-ionization of Rb and Cs Rydberg atoms, a development project for a novel atom trapping device made with ball lenses, which is suitable for plasma and atomic-physics research that requires a stray-field-free experimental volume, and base studies on Rydberg-atom EIT for electric-field sensing.  

The project had broader impact in that methods and components developed in the work may lead into future developments and applications of novel atomic and quantum devices. The study of Coulomb explosion of cold, strongly coupled ion plasma may translate to plasmas in other environments (e. g, astrophysics, inertial- and magnetic-confinement fusion, z-pinch, ion traps).  Graduate and undergraduate students were trained in optical, plasma and atomic-physics research. Two PhD students supported by the project have been graduated, as well as two Masters' students.  These have all received valuable training in the fields of atomic physics, plasma physics and applied optics. Additional students have directly or indirectly benefitted from the project.  

 


Last Modified: 04/15/2022
Modified by: Georg Raithel
